host_templates.alias: Template to check Linux server using SNMP protocol
host_templates.name: OS-Linux-SNMP

information.author: Centreon
information.changelog:
* Update relation between HTPL and STPL
* Correct name of HTPL to use in monitoring procedure

description.value:
Plugin pack to monitor GNU/Linux operating system using SNMP protocole.
Several indicators are available but not linked to the template of host.
You have to use them manually:
* CPU usage
* CPU detailed usage
* Disk-Global (all disk, by name, by ID)
* Disk I/O
* Global Inodes
* Load usage (1m, 5m, 15m)
* Memory usage
* Packets error (all interfaces, by name, by ID)
* Process state
* Swap usage
* Traffic (Bandwidth usage for all interfaces, by name, by ID)
* TCP connection
* Uptime

Pack Plugin pour surveiller les systèmes d\'exploitation GNU/Linux en utilisant le protocole SNMP.
De nombreux indicateurs sont disponibles mais ne sont pas associés au modèle d\'hôte.
Ils doivent être déployés manuellement:
* Utilisation CPU
* Utilisation détaillée du CPU
* Disk-Global (pour toutes les partitions, par nom ou pas ID)
* Disk I/O
* Global Inodes
* Load usage (1m, 5m, 15m)
* Utilisation mémoire
* Erreurs de paquets (all interfaces, by name, by ID)
* Etat d\'un processus
* Utilisation du SWAP
* Trafic (Utilisation de la bande passante pour toutes les interfaces, par nom ou par id)
* TCP connexion
* Uptime

information.monitoring_procedure:
# Monitoring procedure ## Prerequisites This chapter describes the prerequisites installation needed by plugins to run. Prerequistes concerns a RHEL like distribution, you may need to adapt it if you run an other Linux distro. Be sure to have with you the following information: * Read-Only SNMP community * IP Address of the monitoring server ### Install the SNMP service With the `root` user, install the following package and its dependencies: root@yourserver\#> yum install net-snmp ### Configure SNMP on your server 1. Open the file */etc/snmp/snmpd.conf* with your favorite text editor 2. Modify the following lines (Replace the ``): com2sec notConfigUser default 3. Comment all the lines which begin by `view`: view systemview included .1.3.6.1.2 view systemview included .1.3.6.1.2.1.25 4. Just after the previous lines, add the following line: view systemview included .1 5. save the file 6. start the snmp service: service snmpd start 7. Add SNMP to booting services: chkconfig --add snmpd chkconfig --level 2345 snmpd on #### Check your SNMP installation Try to execute this command: $ snmpwalk -v 1 -c .1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1 You should get a response looking like the following: SNMPv2-MIB::sysDescr.0 = STRING: Linux 2.6.18-128.1.10.el5 #1 SMP Thu May 7 10:39:21 EDT 2009 i686 ### SNMP Permissions You need a SNMP read access on following OIDs: * HOST-RESOURCES-MIB: .1.3.6.1.2.1.25 (cpu, uptime, storage, process) * UCD-SNMP-MIB: .1.3.6.1.4.1.2021 (swap, memory, inodes, diskio) * IF-MIB: .1.3.6.1.2.1.2 (traffic) ### Troubleshooting Read [Troubleshooting SNMP](http://documentation.centreon.com/docs/centreon-plugins/en/latest/user/guide.html#snmp); ## Centreon Configuration ### Create a host using the appropriate template Go to *Configuration > Hosts* and click *Add*. Then, fill the form as shown by the following table:
Field Value

Host name

Name of the host

Alias

Host description

IP

Host IP Address

Monitored from

Monitoring Poller to use

Host Multiple Templates

OS-Linux-SNMP-custom

Relations > Parent Hostgroups tab
Click on the *Save* button.
information.name: Linux SNMP
